name: Mumbai
shortDescription: The city of dreams, bustling with energy, Bollywood glamour, and stunning coastal views.
description: Mumbai, the financial capital of India, is a vibrant metropolis that never sleeps. From the iconic Gateway of India to the bustling streets of Colaba, this city offers an incredible mix of colonial architecture, modern skyscrapers, and traditional markets.

topAttractions.description: Iconic monument overlooking the Arabian Sea, built during British rule

topAttractions.name: Marine Drive
topAttractions.description: Scenic 3.6 km long boulevard along the coast, perfect for evening walks

topAttractions.description: Stunning mosque located on an islet off the coast of Worli

travelTips: Local trains are the fastest way to travel, but can be extremely crowded during rush hours
Try street food at Juhu Beach and Mohammed Ali Road
Book Elephanta Caves ferry tickets in advance during peak season
Use Uber or Ola for convenient taxi services
Keep small change handy for local purchases

faqs.question: Is Mumbai safe for solo female travelers?
faqs.answer: Yes, Mumbai is generally safe for solo female travelers. The city has a good public transport system, including women-only compartments in local trains. Stick to well-lit areas at night, use trusted cab services like Uber/Ola, and avoid isolated beaches after dark. Areas like Colaba, Bandra, and Marine Drive are particularly safe for solo travelers.

faqs.question: What can I do in Mumbai in 2 days?
faqs.answer: Day 1: Visit Gateway of India, take a ferry to Elephanta Caves, explore Colaba Causeway, and enjoy sunset at Marine Drive. Day 2: See Haji Ali Dargah, visit Chhatrapati Shivaji Terminus, explore Crawford Market, and experience the nightlife at Bandra. Don't miss trying vada pav and pav bhaji from street vendors.

faqs.question: How much does a Mumbai weekend trip cost?
faqs.answer: A budget weekend trip to Mumbai costs ₹3,000-5,000 including hostel accommodation (₹500-800/night), local transport (₹500), food (₹800-1,200), and attraction tickets (₹500). Mid-range travelers should budget ₹8,000-12,000 for hotel stays, dining at restaurants, and taxi services.

faqs.question: What is the best time to visit Mumbai?
faqs.answer: November to February is the best time to visit Mumbai when the weather is pleasant with temperatures between 15-30°C. Avoid the monsoon season (June-September) due to heavy rainfall. October and March offer good weather with fewer crowds and better hotel rates.

faqs.question: What are the must-try foods in Mumbai?
faqs.answer: Must-try Mumbai foods include Vada Pav (₹15-30), Pav Bhaji (₹80-150), Bhel Puri (₹40-80), Bombay Sandwich, Misal Pav, and Bombay Duck Fry. Visit Mohammed Ali Road for biryani, Juhu Beach for street food, and Bademiya for kebabs. Don't miss Filter Coffee and Cutting Chai.

name: Delhi
shortDescription: India's capital city, a perfect blend of ancient heritage and modern development.
description: Delhi, the heart of India, is a city where history comes alive. From Mughal monuments to British-era buildings, bustling bazaars to modern metro, Delhi offers an unforgettable experience. The city is divided into Old Delhi with its narrow lanes and rich heritage, and New Delhi with wide roads and contemporary architecture.

topAttractions.name: India Gate

topAttractions.description: Beautiful Mughal garden tomb, inspiration for Taj Mahal

travelTips: Delhi Metro is the best way to avoid traffic
Visit monuments early morning to avoid crowds and heat
Try street food at Chandni Chowk, but choose busy stalls
Hire a guide for historical monuments to understand their significance
Be cautious of touts near tourist attractions

faqs.question: Is Delhi safe for tourists?
faqs.answer: Delhi is generally safe for tourists if you take standard precautions. Use Delhi Metro or app-based cabs, avoid isolated areas at night, and keep valuables secure. Tourist areas like Connaught Place, India Gate, and major monuments are well-policed. Solo female travelers should avoid late-night travel and use women-only metro compartments.

faqs.question: How many days do you need in Delhi?
faqs.answer: 3-4 days is ideal to explore Delhi. Day 1: Old Delhi (Red Fort, Jama Masjid, Chandni Chowk). Day 2: New Delhi (India Gate, Rashtrapati Bhavan, Connaught Place). Day 3: South Delhi (Qutub Minar, Humayun's Tomb, Lotus Temple). Day 4: Museums and shopping at Dilli Haat or Sarojini Nagar.

faqs.question: What is the cheapest way to travel in Delhi?
faqs.answer: Delhi Metro is the cheapest and most efficient way to travel, with fares starting at ₹10. DTC buses are even cheaper (₹5-15) but can be crowded. Auto-rickshaws cost ₹25 minimum, while Uber/Ola charge ₹50-100 for short distances. Buy a Delhi Metro Tourist Card (₹200-500) for unlimited travel.

faqs.question: What should I avoid in Delhi?
faqs.answer: Avoid drinking tap water (stick to bottled water), eating street food from unhygienic vendors, and traveling alone late at night. Don't engage with aggressive touts near monuments, avoid unauthorized tour guides, and be cautious of taxi scams at airports. Summer months (May-July) have extreme heat (40-45°C).

faqs.question: What are Delhi's must-visit heritage sites?
faqs.answer: Must-visit heritage sites include Red Fort (₹35 entry), Qutub Minar (₹30), Humayun's Tomb (₹30), India Gate (free), Lotus Temple (free), Jama Masjid (free), and Akshardham Temple (free, closed Mondays). Book a combined ticket for ₹100 to visit multiple ASI monuments.

name: Bangalore
shortDescription: The Silicon Valley of India, known for its pleasant weather, parks, and vibrant culture.
description: Bangalore, officially known as Bengaluru, is India's IT hub and one of the most cosmopolitan cities. Known for its pleasant climate year-round, the city offers beautiful parks, historic palaces, modern shopping malls, and a thriving food scene. It's also the gateway to exploring Karnataka's rich heritage.

faqs.question: What is Bangalore famous for?
faqs.answer: Bangalore is famous for being India's IT hub (Silicon Valley of India), pleasant year-round weather, beautiful parks like Lalbagh and Cubbon Park, vibrant cafe culture, craft breweries, and as the gateway to hill stations like Coorg and Ooty. It's also known for aerospace industry, startup ecosystem, and South Indian cuisine.

faqs.question: How many days are enough for Bangalore?
faqs.answer: 2-3 days is sufficient for Bangalore city. Day 1: Visit Lalbagh Botanical Garden, Bangalore Palace, and Cubbon Park. Day 2: Explore ISKCON Temple, Vidhana Soudha, and Commercial Street for shopping. Day 3: Day trip to Nandi Hills (60 km) or explore Koramangala's cafes and Indiranagar's nightlife.

faqs.question: Is Bangalore expensive for tourists?
faqs.answer: Bangalore is moderately expensive. Budget travelers can manage with ₹1,500-2,500/day (hostel ₹400-600, food ₹500-800, local transport ₹300). Mid-range travelers need ₹3,500-6,000/day with hotel stays (₹2,000-3,500), restaurant meals, and Uber/Ola. Cafes and breweries cost ₹300-800 per person.

faqs.question: What is the best time to visit Bangalore?
faqs.answer: Bangalore has pleasant weather year-round (15-30°C), making it a great destination anytime. October to February offers cooler temperatures (15-25°C) ideal for sightseeing. March to May is warm but comfortable (20-33°C). Monsoon (June-September) brings moderate rainfall and lush greenery.

faqs.question: What are the best weekend getaways from Bangalore?
faqs.answer: Top weekend getaways include Coorg (260 km, coffee plantations), Mysore (150 km, palaces), Ooty (270 km, hill station), Chikmagalur (245 km, coffee estates), Hampi (340 km, UNESCO ruins), Wayanad (275 km, wildlife), and Kabini (220 km, wildlife safari). All are 4-6 hours drive from Bangalore.

name: Jaipur
shortDescription: The Pink City, famous for magnificent palaces, forts, and vibrant Rajasthani culture.
description: Jaipur, the capital of Rajasthan, is famously known as the Pink City due to its distinctive pink-colored buildings. This royal city is home to magnificent forts, opulent palaces, and colorful bazaars. Jaipur forms part of the Golden Triangle tourist circuit and offers a glimpse into India's regal past.

faqs.question: Why is Jaipur called the Pink City?
faqs.answer: Jaipur is called the Pink City because in 1876, Maharaja Ram Singh painted the entire old city pink (terracotta color) to welcome Prince of Wales. Pink symbolizes hospitality in Rajput culture. The tradition continues, and by law, buildings in the old city must maintain their pink facade.

faqs.question: How many days do you need in Jaipur?
faqs.answer: 2-3 days is ideal for Jaipur. Day 1: Amber Fort (elephant ride), Jaigarh Fort, and Nahargarh Fort for sunset. Day 2: City Palace, Hawa Mahal, Jantar Mantar, and shopping at Johari Bazaar. Day 3: Day trip to Pushkar or Ajmer (150 km), or visit Chokhi Dhani for cultural evening.

faqs.question: What is the best time to visit Jaipur?
faqs.answer: November to February is the best time with pleasant weather (10-25°C), ideal for fort exploration. October and March offer good weather with fewer crowds. Avoid April-June (35-45°C extreme heat) and July-September (monsoon). Visit during Jaipur Literature Festival (January) or Diwali for cultural experiences.

faqs.question: Is Jaipur safe for solo female travelers?
faqs.answer: Jaipur is moderately safe for solo female travelers. Tourist areas like Amber Fort, City Palace, and Hawa Mahal are well-policed. Dress modestly, avoid isolated areas after dark, use trusted transport (Uber/Ola), and book reputable accommodations. Be cautious of scams near attractions and aggressive vendors in bazaars.

faqs.question: What should I buy in Jaipur?
faqs.answer: Must-buy items include blue pottery, block-printed textiles, gemstones and jewelry from Johari Bazaar, Mojari (traditional footwear), lac bangles, miniature paintings, and handicrafts. Visit Bapu Bazaar for textiles, Tripolia Bazaar for bangles, and Chandpole for marble items. Bargain at least 30-40% from initial prices.

name: Goa
shortDescription: India's beach paradise with stunning coastline, Portuguese heritage, and vibrant nightlife.
description: Goa, India's smallest state, is famous for its pristine beaches, Portuguese colonial architecture, vibrant nightlife, and laid-back atmosphere. From the party beaches of North Goa to the serene shores of South Goa, this coastal paradise offers something for everyone. Rich in history and natural beauty, Goa is a perfect blend of relaxation and adventure.

faqs.question: Which is better: North Goa or South Goa?
faqs.answer: North Goa is better for nightlife, water sports, and party scenes (Baga, Calangute, Anjuna beaches). South Goa offers peaceful beaches, luxury resorts, and relaxation (Palolem, Agonda, Cavelossim). Solo travelers and young couples prefer North Goa, while families and honeymooners choose South Goa. Budget ₹2,500-4,000/day for North, ₹4,000-8,000/day for South.

faqs.question: How many days are enough for Goa?
faqs.answer: 4-5 days is ideal for Goa. Day 1-2: North Goa beaches (Baga, Calangute, Anjuna), Fort Aguada. Day 3: Old Goa churches (Basilica of Bom Jesus), spice plantation. Day 4: South Goa beaches (Palolem, Agonda). Day 5: Dudhsagar Falls or water sports. Add 2-3 days for complete relaxation or island hopping.

faqs.question: What is the cheapest month to visit Goa?
faqs.answer: May to September (monsoon season) is the cheapest time with 50-70% lower hotel rates. Budget accommodations cost ₹500-1,000/night vs ₹2,000-4,000 in peak season (December-January). Flights and activities are also cheaper. However, beaches have rough seas, some shacks close, and water sports are limited. Best budget time: September-October (post-monsoon).

faqs.question: Is Goa safe for solo female travelers?
faqs.answer: Goa is generally safe for solo female travelers, especially in tourist areas. Stay in reputable accommodations, avoid isolated beaches at night, don't accept drinks from strangers, and use licensed taxis/bike rentals. South Goa beaches like Palolem and Agonda are safer and more peaceful. Dress modestly when visiting churches and temples.

faqs.question: What should I avoid in Goa?
faqs.answer: Avoid drinking tap water (use bottled), illegal drugs (strict penalties), unregulated water sports operators, unlicensed taxis, isolated beaches at night, and disrespecting religious sites. Don't carry expensive jewelry, leave valuables unattended on beaches, or swim in red-flag areas. Avoid peak season (Christmas-New Year) for budget travel due to 3-4x price increases.
